hypothesis: In Securities (NAICS 523), wages are declining (-2.4%) while employment grows (+4.1%). This is the inverse of a traditional Baumol cost disease squeeze. If this pattern represents AI's structural effect on high-wage knowledge work — compressing the wage premium by replacing expensive roles with lower-cost AI-augmented positions — it should appear in other high-Baumol professional sectors as AI adoption reaches critical mass.

test_sectors: 5411 Legal Services (Baumol ~2.44, highest fear friction at 82% ethical concern)
524 Insurance Carriers (Baumol ~2.05, high automation readiness, low fear friction)
test_design.data_source: BLS QCEW Annual Averages 2022-2023 (private sector, national)
test_design.signal_definition: Inverse Baumol = wages declining year-over-year while employment is growing or stable. The opposite of a classic Baumol squeeze where wages rise because labor supply is constrained.
alternative_outcomes: Classic Baumol squeeze: wages up, employment up (stored energy building)
Contraction: wages down, employment down (sector shrinking)
Inverse Baumol: wages down, employment up or stable (AI compressing wage premium)

523_securities.sector_name: Securities, Commodity Contracts, and Other Financial Investments
523_securities.analysis: Wages declining in consecutive years (-1.9%, then -2.4%) while employment growing (+5.8%, then +4.1%). The wage decline is ACCELERATING while employment growth is DECELERATING — consistent with a composition shift where high-comp roles (traders, analysts) are replaced by lower-comp AI-augmented operations staff. Total payroll still growing (+1.6%) because more bodies at lower per-head cost.
supplementary_evidence: Goldman Sachs AI profits +56%, JPMorgan +35% (AI generating revenue while compressing headcount costs)
FS lost 22,000 jobs in Jan 2026 (BLS) — first major monthly decline
Entry-level analyst hiring down 24pp (junior roles being eliminated first)
Record RIA M&A: 345 deals in Q3 2025 ($1.22T transacted)

5411_legal_services.analysis: Wages rising faster than employment in both years (4.3% vs 1.9%, then 3.8% vs 0.5%). Classic stored-energy Baumol squeeze — the sector is accumulating disruption pressure. Employment growth nearly stalled at +0.5% in 2023 while wages rose 3.8%, suggesting the labor pool is tightening as the sector resists automation. This is a pre-disruption signal, not yet Inverse Baumol.
leading_indicators_toward_inverse_baumol: Employment growth decelerating sharply: 1.9% → 0.5% (approaching stall)
Baker McKenzie laid off ~700 staff (Feb 2026), citing AI as contributing factor
Clifford Chance cut ~50 London roles (10% of office), cited AI
64% of in-house teams expect to reduce outside counsel dependence due to AI
31% of legal professionals now personally use generative AI (up from <10% in 2023)
22% of legal tasks automatable today, 44% technically automatable (McKinsey)

factors: 82% ethical concerns about AI in legal practice (highest of any professional sector)
AI hallucination of case citations creates professional liability risk
Only 39% of firms with 51+ lawyers using AI (vs 52% in-house corporate legal)
Low risk tolerance in legal practice — errors have legal consequences
MIT economist: 'some impact but not major' due to error intolerance

5411_legal_services.flip_mechanism: In-house AI adoption (52%) reducing outside counsel demand → law firm revenue compression → junior associate hiring freeze → wage compression starts at entry level and propagates upward. Baker McKenzie layoffs may be the first visible crack.

5412_accounting_tax_prep.sector_name: Accounting, Tax Preparation, Bookkeeping, and Payroll Services
5412_accounting_tax_prep.analysis: The most significant finding across all test sectors. Wage growth decelerated DRAMATICALLY from +6.6% to +2.9% (a 56% deceleration) in a single year, while employment growth halved from 5.5% to 3.0%. The wage-employment gap that was +1.1pp in 2021-2022 became -0.1pp in 2022-2023 — the rates are now EQUAL, meaning the classic Baumol squeeze has effectively disappeared. One more year of this trajectory would produce the Inverse Baumol signature. Establishment growth remains high (+5.0%), suggesting Coasean shrinkage (T10) — more small firms forming as AI enables solo practitioners.
leading_indicators_toward_inverse_baumol: Wage growth decelerated from +6.6% to +2.9% in one year — approaching zero differential
AI adoption exploded from 9% to 41% in one year (2024→2025)
Entry-level hiring declined 16% over 2 years (Stanford 2025)
CPA pipeline dropped ~50% between 1990-2021; 300K+ accountants left since 2020
75% of current CPAs approaching retirement age
15-20% fewer entry-level positions projected by 2027
Establishment growth +5.0% while employment growth only +3.0% = Coasean signal
Tech-optimized firms hitting $250K-$350K revenue/employee vs $150K-$200K traditional

factors: 53% view AI favorably; 46% use AI daily
Only 25% have formal AI policies (adoption outpacing governance)
CPA shortage creating receptivity to automation
Low error intolerance for routine tasks (bookkeeping, payroll, tax prep)
High error intolerance for audit and advisory (human premium persists)

5412_accounting_tax_prep.flip_mechanism: The convergence of wage and employment growth rates strongly suggests the flip is imminent or may have already occurred in 2024 data (not yet available in QCEW). The mechanism: AI automates entry-level tasks → entry-level hiring declines 16% → average wage per employee drops as junior cohort shrinks and is replaced by AI tools. Meanwhile, establishment growth stays high because AI enables smaller firms to compete, adding bodies at lower per-head cost. The CPA pipeline crisis ACCELERATES this because firms can't find expensive senior CPAs and are forced to substitute AI for entry-level labor.

524_insurance_carriers.analysis: Both employment and wages growing, with wages outpacing employment (Baumol squeeze still active). The gap is narrowing (4.4% vs 2.9% = +1.5pp gap in 2022, then 3.8% vs 2.1% = +1.7pp in 2023). Growth rates are decelerating across the board. Insurance has the lowest fear friction of all test sectors and is adopting AI most aggressively (35% deploying across 3+ functions by late 2026), but the sheer size of the sector (2.56M workers) and regulatory barriers create inertia. The Inverse Baumol flip is likely 2-3 years behind Securities.
leading_indicators_toward_inverse_baumol: Claims automation: straightforward claims now settled in minutes by agentic AI
Processing time reduction up to 70% for automated processes
35%+ of insurers deploying AI agents across 3+ core functions by late 2026
AI skills now baseline requirement for underwriting roles
Industry described as becoming 'AI operating system' by 2026
Lowest fear friction of any test sector

factors: Insurance inherently data-driven and quantitative — cultural fit for AI
Regulators more accommodating than legal profession
Claims automation broadly accepted by industry
New revenue opportunity: AI-specific insurance policies emerging
Historical comfort with actuarial models and algorithmic decision-making

524_insurance_carriers.flip_mechanism: Claims processing automation eliminates routine adjuster roles → average wage per employee drops as composition shifts from adjusters ($50-70K) to AI engineers ($120-150K) but with far fewer AI engineers needed per claims volume. Underwriting automation follows. The large workforce (2.56M) means even small percentage changes represent massive absolute numbers. Regulatory pace (state-by-state insurance regulation) slows the transition.

fear_friction_vs_timeline.observation: Fear friction is the primary predictor of WHEN the Inverse Baumol flip occurs, not the magnitude of AI capability. Securities (low fear, data-native culture) flipped first. Accounting (medium-low fear, practical culture) is converging now. Legal (high fear, error-intolerant culture) is 2-3 years behind. Insurance (low fear but large/regulated) is on a parallel but slower track.
fear_friction_vs_timeline.note: Insurance has lower fear friction than Legal but higher predicted flip year because of sector size (2.56M vs 1.18M workers) and state-by-state regulatory friction. The flip timing formula appears to be: f(fear_friction, sector_size, regulatory_complexity, AI_task_fit).

cross_sector_comparison.key_divergence: The most striking finding is Accounting (5412). Wage growth collapsed from +6.6% to +2.9% in a single year while AI adoption jumped from 9% to 41%. This is the fastest approach to an Inverse Baumol flip in the data. If the 2024 QCEW data (available ~Q3 2026) shows wage growth below employment growth, P-040 will be confirmed as cross-sector.

pattern_status_update.summary: P-040 Inverse Baumol Effect is confirmed in Securities and shows strong convergence in Accounting. Legal and Insurance are in pre-disruption phases with clear leading indicators. The pattern represents a structural mechanism: AI compresses the wage premium in knowledge work by automating high-cost junior/routine tasks, allowing firms to add lower-cost AI-augmented roles while total employment grows or stays flat. Fear friction is the primary timing variable.
falsification_criteria: If 2024 QCEW data shows Accounting wage growth RE-ACCELERATING above employment growth, the convergence is not structural
If Legal employment growth rebounds above 2% while wages continue rising 4%+, the Baumol squeeze is sustainable
If Insurance wages accelerate despite AI adoption, the pattern is Securities-specific (possibly driven by market structure, not AI)
If Securities wage decline reverses in 2024-2025, the pattern may be cyclical (market-driven) rather than structural (AI-driven)
pattern_status_update.cross_force_interaction: P-040 is amplified by F2 (Demographics) — the CPA pipeline collapse and Securities advisor retirement wave (38% within a decade) create labor supply constraints that FORCE firms to adopt AI, accelerating the composition shift. The pattern may be strongest where demographic supply collapse (T8) and Baumol cost disease (T3) intersect.

new_insights.insight: Coasean Shrinkage as Inverse Baumol Precursor
new_insights.detail: Accounting shows +5.0% establishment growth with only +3.0% employment growth — firms are forming faster than workers are being hired. This Coasean signal (T10) may be a leading indicator for the Inverse Baumol flip: AI enables smaller firms to compete at lower per-head cost, which shows up as establishment growth outpacing employment growth BEFORE average wages decline.
new_insights.testable_prediction: Sectors where establishment growth exceeds employment growth by >2pp will flip to Inverse Baumol within 2-3 years.

new_insights.detail: The four test sectors provide a natural experiment in fear friction as a timing variable. Securities (15) flipped in 2021-2022, Accounting (35) is converging in 2023-2024, Legal (82) is 3-4 years behind Securities. This suggests a rough formula: flip_delay_years ≈ fear_friction_score / 20.
new_insights.testable_prediction: If fear_friction / 20 ≈ years behind Securities' flip, then Legal should flip ~4 years after Securities (2025-2026), and this can be verified with 2025 QCEW data.

new_insights.insight: Entry-Level Extinction as Inverse Baumol Mechanism
new_insights.detail: The Inverse Baumol effect appears to operate through entry-level role elimination. Securities: entry-level analyst hiring -24pp. Accounting: entry-level hiring -16%. Legal: Baker McKenzie laying off junior staff. The mechanism is: AI automates junior tasks → entry-level cohort shrinks → average wage per employee drops because the removed cohort was lower-paid than the remaining experienced workers. Wait — this is the OPPOSITE of what we'd expect. If junior (lower-paid) roles are eliminated, average wage should RISE not fall.
new_insights.reconciliation: The wage decline in Securities occurs because high-paid front-office roles (traders, analysts earning $200-400K) are being replaced by lower-paid AI-augmented operations roles ($80-120K). The entry-level extinction is the VISIBLE symptom, but the actual wage compression happens at the MID-TO-SENIOR level where AI replaces expensive human judgment with cheaper algorithmic execution. Both phenomena occur simultaneously.
new_insights.testable_prediction: Decomposing Securities wage data by experience level should show that mid-senior compensation is falling faster than junior compensation.

recommendations_for_v38_scoring.legal_services_models: Existing Legal Services models should have TG (Timing Grade) adjusted downward by 1-2 points to reflect that the Baumol squeeze is still active, not yet flipping. Fear friction score of 82 creates significant timing uncertainty.
recommendations_for_v38_scoring.accounting_models: Accounting models should have TG adjusted UPWARD by 1-2 points. The convergence is happening faster than projected. AI adoption 9%→41% in one year suggests the flip could occur in 2025 data.
recommendations_for_v38_scoring.insurance_models: Insurance models maintain current TG. The sector is large and slow-moving despite low fear friction. No Inverse Baumol signal yet.
recommendations_for_v38_scoring.new_pattern_interaction: P-040 should be cross-referenced with P-027 (Staffing Canary), P-032 (Invisible Entry Pathway), and P-039 (Healthcare Monoculture) to build a composite model of AI's structural labor market effects.
